practicalities.parking: Ample informal parking along the dirt track overlooking the various peaks.
practicalities.facilities: None. Nearest facilities are in Majanicho or El Cotillo.
practicalities.paddleOut: Use the channel to paddle out.
practicalities.additionalTips: This is first and foremost a windsurf spot. If windsurfers are rigging or start sailing, you should leave or not enter the water for your own safety.

spots.description:
Punta del Tigre roars to life in Fuerteventura's dramatic southern wilderness near Punta de Jandía, where raw Atlantic energy detonates over a rugged volcanic reef. This exposed beast is famous for delivering powerful, hollow cylinders that challenge even the most experienced surfers seeking tube time. The spot's remote location ensures solitude, with just the dramatic coastal landscape as your audience. The left-hander here wraps around the point, creating long, perfectly shaped walls that can hold size and offer multiple barrel sections.

When the swell aligns, Punta del Tigre serves up thrilling, barreling sections that test your nerve and reward courage with unforgettable rides in one of the island's most spectacular settings. This is serious territory for advanced surfers who appreciate raw power and pristine natural beauty. The wave breaks over unforgiving volcanic rock that can create dredging barrels when the tide is right, making every successful ride feel like a major accomplishment.

The journey to Punta del Tigre is part of the adventure - requiring a rugged 4WD trek through some of the island's most remote and beautiful landscapes. This isolation means you'll often have the wave to yourself or with a small crew of dedicated locals who understand its dangers and rewards. The dramatic cliffs and untouched coastline create a sense of timelessness here, where the only sounds are the crashing waves and the occasional calls of seabirds. It's a place where surfing returns to its purest form - just you, the ocean, and one of the most powerful waves in the Canaries.

waveDetails.idealConditions: Works best when a Southwest groundswell combines with an offshore north wind. An inconsistent spot that does not work very often, with optimal conditions more frequent in winter.

characteristics.localVibe: Solitary and secluded.

practicalities.access: Access via the very long and rough dirt track leading to the Punta de Jandía lighthouse. A 4x4 vehicle is strongly recommended.
practicalities.parking: Informal parking near the end of the track.
practicalities.facilities: None. One of the most remote parts of the island.
practicalities.paddleOut: Extremely difficult entry over sharp volcanic rock. High risk of injury and board damage. Expert only.
practicalities.additionalTips: Due to its isolated location and powerful waves, this spot requires self-sufficiency and caution. The wave is very inconsistent and often too small, but can provide excellent conditions when it works.

spots.description:
A prominent reef break strategically positioned between the island of Lobos and Corralejo, serving as a sanctuary when the North Shore swells grow too powerful. This spot transforms into a wave paradise with long, shoulder-breaking right-handers on the outside section, while the inside area offers playful, faster lefts and rights perfect for honing your skills.

The beauty of Punta Elena lies in its versatility - the outer reef delivers those dreamy, long rides that intermediate surfers crave, making it particularly famous among longboarders and SUP enthusiasts seeking quality wave time. When the main breaks are closing out, you'll find this spot working beautifully, offering consistent shoulders that seem to go on forever.

Smart access is key here - instead of tackling the treacherous lava rock hike, paddle in 'around the corner' for a much safer entry. During the prime months between November and March, this spot really shows its character, providing that perfect escape when other spots are maxed out.

waveDetails.directionNotes: Primary outside is a right, inside offers lefts and rights.
waveDetails.idealConditions: Starts working when the North Shore is getting big. The outside offers long, guaranteed right shoulders, while the inside provides faster sections.

characteristics.localVibe: Popular and accessible spot.

practicalities.access: From Corralejo, follow 'Avenida grandes playas' until the bar 'Pura-vida', then take the next left. Park and take the small path down to the waterfront, which brings you out directly in front of the left-hander.
practicalities.parking: Street parking available.
practicalities.facilities: Bars and amenities of Corralejo are nearby.
practicalities.paddleOut: Tip: Launch your board behind the corner to avoid a long and painful rocky walk.

spots.description:
A beautifully sheltered left-hand point break that serves as North Shore's ultimate sanctuary when conditions turn challenging elsewhere. This remarkable spot transforms unruly swells into perfectly shaped waves that peel predictably into the bay, offering multiple sections to play with and explore.

What makes Punta Gorda truly special is its remarkable resilience - even when strong onshore winds are wreaking havoc on other breaks, this protected corner maintains clean, rideable faces. Large swells undergo a magical transformation as they reform over the shallow take-off zone, creating a beautiful left-hander with several distinct sections that allow for both strategic maneuvering and pure cruising pleasure.

Be prepared for a workout though - the bay's natural geography creates a persistent current that demands constant paddling to maintain position. This physical challenge is more than worth it for the reward of perfectly formed waves when everywhere else is blown out or maxed out.

waveDetails.idealConditions: Works when other spots are oversized or windy. Even surfable with a strong onshore wind. The wave reforms on a often shallow take-off zone before peeling left.

characteristics.localVibe: Protected by locals; respect is essential.

practicalities.access: Accessible via the western end of the North Shore dirt track, starting from near El Cotillo.
practicalities.parking: Informal parking on the cliffs overlooking the break.
practicalities.facilities: None. Nearest facilities are in El Cotillo.
practicalities.paddleOut: Non-stop paddling is a must to fight the strong current.
practicalities.additionalTips: The current can suck you towards the rocks if you lose your position. Watch how the local surfers manage the lineup and avoid messing up the peak.

spots.description:
Where maritime history meets surfing perfection, Playa de Garcey stands as one of Fuerteventura's most historically significant surf destinations. This remote wild west coast bay earned its place in history as the final resting place of the SS American Star shipwreck, which ran aground here on January 18, 1994, creating a legendary tale that still captivates visitors today. The rusting remnants of this once-majestic ocean liner served as a surreal surfing landmark for years, though time and tide have largely claimed the wreck back to the Atlantic.

What makes Playa de Garcey truly special among west coast spots is its unique geography that creates an oasis of protection in an otherwise exposed coastline. Unlike its neighboring breaks that bear the full brunt of Atlantic force, this bay's configuration provides lighter and often offshore wind conditions, transforming what could be punishing sessions into perfect surfing opportunities. The spot delivers a versatile beach break with distinct left and right-hand peaks that work in harmony, while a relatively safe channel provides easy paddle-out access that eliminates the grueling battles common to other west coast locations.

The friendly, sheltered atmosphere of Playa de Garcey creates an inclusive environment that welcomes surfers of all abilities. Beginners can find their confidence in the manageable white water, while advanced surfers push their limits on the main peaks that offer both power and maneuverability. The bay's protected nature means consistent, rideable waves even when other spots are blown out or maxed out. This combination of historical significance, unique geography, and user-friendly conditions makes Playa de Garcey a must-visit destination where surfing culture and maritime heritage create an unforgettable experience on Fuerteventura's rugged west coast.

waveDetails.directionNotes: Right on the north side, Left on the south side.
waveDetails.idealConditions: Works on west/northwest swells. The bay is uniquely sheltered, often creating offshore conditions. It handles larger swells well without closing out as easily as other beach breaks. Best for beginners at low tide with gentle white water; ideal for intermediates at mid-tide; advanced surfers find more powerful, larger waves at high tide.

characteristics.localVibe: Friendly and popular with local families and campers; a respected spot where a friendly attitude is appreciated.
hazards: Two currents: safe channel (north) & dangerous cliff-bound current (south)
Rocks/round stones on bottom after storms
Optical illusion - waves are stronger than they appear from the cliff

practicalities.access: Extremely challenging. A 4x4 vehicle is ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL for the very rough, unmaintained gravel road. From the main road to La Pared, look for the small 'Playa de Garcey' sign in the valley after the second mountain ridge.
practicalities.parking: Park at the beginning of the bay. Driving onto the beach itself is prohibited.
practicalities.facilities: None. Totally remote; bring all supplies including water.
practicalities.paddleOut: Use the relatively safe and gentle channel on the northern end of the bay to get to the lineup. Avoid the southern end.
practicalities.additionalTips: The wreckage is sharp and surrounded by unpredictable currents - observe from a distance. Be aware of your position to avoid being swept south towards the cliffs by the current. The waves are consistently more powerful than they look from the cliff top. A great fallback when other west coast spots are too windy or oversized.

spots.description:
The legendary terror of Fuerteventura's infamous North Shore advanced breaks cluster, Suicidios earns its ominous alternative name "Suicides" through sheer wave brutality. Situated between Corralejo and El Cotillo, this spot forms part of the island's most feared coastline, where exposed reef formations create some of the heaviest waves in the Canaries. The name itself serves as a warning - this is genuinely gnarly and suicidal territory that demands total respect from those who dare to challenge it.

When conditions align, Suicidios unleashes a terrifying right-hand monster that breaks over sharp lava reef with unapologetic force. The wave's two distinct sections offer different kinds of punishment: the first section is notoriously impossible to make, serving as a testing ground for only the most committed, while the second provides those rare, makeable barrels that become lifelong achievements. Both right and left reef breaks work here, but the right-handers are the stuff of local legend, capable of producing freight-train tubes across the exposed reef shelf.

This is unequivocally expert-only territory where local knowledge isn't just recommended - it's essential for survival. The wave's reputation as "suicidal" comes from its combination of extreme shallow water razor-sharp reef, raw power, and unforgiving sections that rarely offer mistakes. For the select few who master this break, Suicidios delivers the barrel of a lifetime, but the price of failure is severe. This spot represents the ultimate test of courage, skill, and wave-reading ability on Fuerteventura's treacherous North Shore.

waveDetails.directionNotes: Main break is a right, also a shorter inside Left.
waveDetails.idealConditions: Works best on a North-Northwest swell combined with an offshore South-Southeast wind. A consistent spot that is just as likely to work on local windswells as on distant groundswells. Holds swells up to 3 meters (10 feet).

characteristics.crowdNotes: Sometimes crowded; surfed by a handful of highly skilled locals.
characteristics.localVibe: Competitive and reserved for experts; high respect for locals is mandatory

practicalities.access: Located along the northern dirt track. Follow it until you reach a vast lava field close to the coast. The walk to the spot is instant (less than 5 minutes).
practicalities.parking: Available along the North Track
practicalities.facilities: None
practicalities.paddleOut: Challenging; getting into the water over sharp lava rock can be a hazard on bigger swells
practicalities.additionalTips: Wearing a helmet is recommended. This is not a spot for windsurfing or kitesurfing. It is crucial to watch the locals, talk to them, and assess your skill level honestly before even considering paddling out.

spots.description:
Waikiki Beach, also known as Playa Waikiki or Galera Beach, sits as a sheltered oasis in the very heart of Corralejo town, offering one of the most accessible and versatile surfing experiences on the island. This prime beachfront location features a dedicated Waikiki Beach Club right on the sand with sweeping sea views, surrounded by a vibrant tourism infrastructure of hotels and apartments.

The bay's natural protection creates perfect conditions for multiple watersports - it's famous as a primary hub for wing foiling and windsurfing, while also offering gentle, accessible waves in the middle of the bay that make it ideal for beginner surfers. The easy access from town center means you can walk from your accommodation to the water within minutes.

What makes Waikiki Beach truly special is its year-round consistency and protection from harsh conditions. The sheltered bay shields beginners from strong winds and currents while providing reliable learning waves, yet still offers enough power for progression when the conditions align. Near the magnificent Corralejo Dunes, this spot combines convenience with natural beauty.

waveDetails.directionNotes: Gentle, reforming waves in the middle of the bay.
waveDetails.idealConditions: Works on northwest swells, typically in winter and autumn. The bay is well-protected, resulting in smaller, manageable waves ideal for beginners.

characteristics.localVibe: Lively and accessible, shared by wingfoilers, windsurfers, and beginner surfers.

practicalities.access: Extremely easy access from the beaches of Corralejo. A concrete pier allows water users to bypass the reef and enter the sea safely at all tide levels.
practicalities.parking: Available in the town of Corralejo
practicalities.facilities: The area is lined with several bars, restaurants, and commerce, making it a convenient and lively spot.
practicalities.paddleOut: Easy, either directly from the beach or via the concrete pier.
